captions.text:
Zebras. They're kind of the David Bowies of
the Mammalian World. [Quietly] Isn't David
Bowie a mammal?

There's no question that the stripes are stylish,
but why do zebras have them?

Well, a lot of theories have to do with camouflage,
and this may seem counter-intuitive given

the distinct lack of zebra print environments
in nature, but really camouflage can work

in lots of different ways. Like, sometimes
it's about the pattern, not the coloration.

Because, to a colorblind lion, these stripes
blend in nicely with tall grasses.

Zebra camouflage may also work through optical
illusions. As highly social animals, zebras

live in herds, and when they're together,
all those stripes can make it hard for a creeping

predator to single out any one of them. A
herd of striped equines may just look like

a big blob of crazy. New computer simulations
of zebras in motion even suggest that specific

and spectacularly disorientating illusions
are at work. Have you ever noticed how when

a spinning wheel reaches a certain speed,
the so-called "Wagon-Wheel Effect" kicks in

and it looks like it's actually turning backwards?
Or how even though that the iconic barber

shop pole rotates horizontally it looks like
those stripes are moving up and down? Well,

a herd of moving zebra can induce both those
types of optical illusions, helping to further
confuse predators.

It also seems that striping may help ward
off biting insects, which is awesome because

a lot of insects have diseases. Horse-flies,
for example, are typically attracted to dark

colors over light ones, but researchers have
recently found out that narrow, densely packed

striping is basically the least attractive
coloration to hungry horse-flies. Less appealing

than either solid black or solid white. So
maybe these stripes are a natural bug repellant.

And interestingly, zebras' striped patterns
are as unique as fingerprints - no two are

the same. So, they may even help the animals
recognize each other.

There you have it; zebra stripes. Fabulous
and functional.

Thanks for asking, and thanks especially to
our Subbable subscribers who keep these answers
coming.

If you have a quick question, let us know
on Facebook or Twitter, or in the comments
below.

And if you want to keep getting smarter with
us, just go to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.

comments.text:
Lions are color blind? Poor kitties...
I wonder why a lot of other mammals are color bind? You would think that 
being able to see a full range of visible wavelengths would be a huge 
advantage, especially if you are a predator.﻿
comments.author: Achuk Martin

comments.text:
It's all about rods and cones. If you can't see color, it means you can see 
at night. If all you have are rods, you can pretty much see at night. 
Humans see better at night if they look with their peripheral vision, 
because our rods are on the sides of our eyes but not in the focal point, 
where we have cones. Lions have rods everywhere, and so they can focus at 
night. 

And lifespan has nothing to do with how quickly you can reproduce, sort of. 
The real reason is you get cancer if you try to live forever. The only way 
a long lifespan would lower your reproduction rate is overpopulation.

But people just didn't evolve to have shorter lifespans because that would 
make them reproduce more quickly.
comments.author: Michael Currier

comments.text:
well since they hunt at night mostly, color isnt the issue. they just need 
to be able to see better than their prey.
comments.author: Jon Newberry

comments.text:
+Vee Logation I don't know about evolving away from not having cones in 
their eyes being the reason for many mammals being color blind, but rather 
they might have never had them. Also, compared to most other animals, most 
mammals have the longest lifespans, especially humans. Most mammals are 
focused less on reproducing as many offspring as quickly as possible and 
more on nurturing and raising our offspring to ensure their survival. The 
ones that reproduce more and faster with short lifespans are insects, some 
amphibians, etc.
comments.author: rinrinnnya

comments.text:
So this is a trade-off, just like w/ our own vision and sense of smell. 
Thanks!
comments.author: Achuk Martin

comments.text:
Probably just that the colours they don't need to see in order to survive 
well enough for long enough to reproduce they end up evolving away from, 
since quite often evolving to have one trait means not being able to have 
another. Kind of like how (if I recall correctly) a longer lifespan usually 
means being less successful at reproducing. So in a way we have evolved to 
have shorter lifespans, because those who mutated to have shorter average 
lifespans were able to reproduce more and faster than the others.

comments.author: StatManSteve

comments.text:
Yeah, I'd like to know how the Zebra knew that the Lion was color blind and 
then unconsciously over time started sprouting stripes? Or, is this just 
some sort of weird evolution/survival of the fittest thing at work here, so 
only the Zebras with stripes back in the day survived? I guess I'm asking 
the question, more or less of, when did the Zebra start getting stripes, 
did they always have them, and how did they know to have stripes in the 
first place. I guess this question goes for all animals that have special 
camouflage. ﻿
comments.author: Joe Blow

comments.text:
It would have started as a genetic mutation. Because of the stripes ( or 
other natural camouflages) would have given it a better chance of survival 
and help it spread its genes around. So then it's children that inherited 
the mutation would have given it a better chance of survival. And so the 
circle continues. So over time stripes or spots or whatever won out. So yes 
it is survival of the fittest or more camouflaged.
comments.author: Naomi Menday Lee

comments.text:
+Joe Blow It can even be that the ones with mutations that are better 
suited to their environment just reproduce more and faster than the others. 
Because then the species as a whole gets more of that trait. And the 
'surviving for longer' consequence only lasts as long as the animals are 
reproductive too, which is interesting.
comments.author: Vee Logation

up instead.

against lions or mosquitoes.

migration.﻿
comments.author: Duane Lortie

comments.text:
Yes and no example AB neg is extremely rare here in the US, not so much in 
England, also a few years ago a group of epidemiologist did a study to see 
if flies had preference by blood type; turns out they do.
Dogs do have blood types but the first transfusion is a freebie before the 
body can mount a reaction all the transfused cells are dead and gone but 
the next time a nonmatch blood transfusion is tried the immune system 
reacts much more quickly and aggressively with dangerous consqueces.

comments.text:
+jimlovesgina Hungryhippocrite was right. And so are you - mostly.

The speed of light in a vacuum is constant.

Your second sentence is entirely correct. You are just missing that the 
reason for the changes of the refractive index is that the speed of light 
in that medium changes with its density.
comments.author: Ole Hansen

comments.text:
+Hungryhippocrite
The speed of light is constant.  The reason air appears to bend or move is 
the refractive index of air changes with temperature.
comments.author: jimlovesgina

comments.text:
+Hungryhippocrite Ah, thank you! And a cool bo burnham reference in your 
name.
comments.author: SectorCodec

comments.text:
It's surprisingly simple, hot air is less dense than colder air; because 
the particles have more kinetic energy and some other factors. The speed at 
which light travels differs depending upon what kind of medium it's 
travelling through, so as light travels through the gradient of cold to hot 
air it's speed changes and due to that its direction aswell. This is called 
refraction, and happens continously to give the effect of 'wavy-ness'. It's 
also responsible for desert mirages which is pretty cool.

comments.author: DJ Syntic

comments.text:
+Michael Cooksey With "statements" do mean the rest of my comment or both 
mine and +DJ Syntic's comments?

Since your comments is placed as a sub-comment under mine, the only reason 
to use qoutation marks and dots is to single out that part of my comment as 
indepent from the rest of it.

Just writing "what" and thereby forcing me to guess your intentions is 
arrogant and pitiful.
E.g. "You may return to ..."
What?

Furthermore, it still doesn't motivate using "...." at the end nor the 
incorrect amount of dots.

It can't be a side note, since it directly relates to my comment.

At least I'm intellectual enough to install a dictionary to my browser and 
thereby avoiding to misspell "intellectual".

I clarified that I included being able to be riden in tamed, the article 
you linked doesn't. It does however confirm my original overall claim that 
their is more differences between horses and zebras than just the colours.

I should, however, have clarified that zebras can't be FULLY tamed, because 
of their genes.

BTW, we don't have meth trailers where I'm from.

comments.author: gaby sanchez

comments.text:
I wish more people could be more like you. A lot of people do like to 
argue, but with aggression and vulgarity. And I've seen so many Youtube 
arguments which main topic was religion, it it seemed to me whoever joined 
in got stirred up. Civilized arguments, that's whats good. Even I would 
start being a complete jerk if we talked about religion. So I thank you, 
for existing with the personality you have.
comments.author: Ango Ango

comments.text:
+Peter.S. Vincello Sometimes arguments are good, because they help us 
explore, (re-)evaluate and expand our beliefs.
